titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Paul Kagan Photographs of Utopian Communities and Personal Papers
Kagan (Paul) Photographs of Utopian Communities and Personal Papers
titlestmt.author: by Matthew Daniel Mason

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 07:13

did.unittitle: Paul Kagan photographs of utopian communities and personal papers

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract:
Chiefly photographs created and copied by Kagan while conducting research for his book, New World Utopias: A Photographic History of the Search for Community. The photographs document nineteenth- and twentieth-century utopian communities, most located in California, with others in New Mexico, Pennsylvania, and Tennessee. The collection includes material that Kagan collected about utopian communities, including audiotapes of interviews and related events, as well as drawings and photographs. The collection also includes examples of photography and graphic design that Kagan created for traditional and alternative newspapers, as well as examples of some of his book reviews and other writings. A small group of material documents social action at the University of California, Berkeley, and in the San Francisco Bay area during the 1960s.
Utopian communities and other groups represented in the collection include an unidentified Amish community, Ananda Ashrama, Caspar Compound, Divine Light Mission, Esoteric Fraternity, The Farm, Fundación Indra Devi, Fountaingrove, Fountain of the World, Halcyon, Holy City, Icaria Speranza, Kaweah Colony, Krotona (including Happy Valley School), Lama Foundation, Lemurian Fellowship, Llano del Rio, The Lord's Land, Pisgah Faith Home, Pisgah Grande, Point Loma, Rosicrucian Fellowship, Questhaven Retreat, Self-Realization Golden World Colony, Table Mountain Ranch, Tassajara Zen Mountain Center, Theosophical Society (Pasadena), Unification Church, and Vedanta Temple (Santa Barbara).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Sue Kagan on the Frederick W. & Carrie S. Beinecke Fund for Western Americana 2010.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Boxes 18-19: Copy photographs are for reference use only, and are not to be reproduced. For further information consult the appropriate curator.
Box 20 (audiocassettes): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies are available in Box 20. Consult Access Services for further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Paul Kagan Photographs of Utopian Communities and Personal Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Copyright to the photographs in the collection created by Paul Kagan belong to Yale University. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Paul Kagan Photographs of Utopian Communities and Personal Papers. Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Much of the biographical and historical information about the photographs derives from Paul Kagan, New World Utopias: A Photographic History of the Search for Community (New York: Penguin Books, 1975).

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Paul Kagan Utopian Communities Collection (WA MSS S-1737)
Walter Millsap / Keikichi Akana Imamura Family Papers (WA MSS S-1590)

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Paul Kagan, photographer and author of the book New World Utopia s, was born in 1943. After receiving a degree in history from the University of California at Berkeley in 1965, he worked as a television news writer, photographer, graphic artist, and magazine art director. Kagan spent five years researching New World Utopias: A Photographic History of the Search for Community (New York: Penguin Books, 1975). Initially, the National Institute of Mental Health provided funds for Kagan to photograph the remains of California 'utopias'; a few years into the project the California Historical Society gave him funds to research and collect the records and contemporary photographs of those communities. During this time Kagan organized the Utopian Studies Center at the California Historical Society Library (San Francisco). At the time of the book's publication, Kagan described himself as writer/researcher and still photographer for the Television Health Information Project at University of California Medical Center, San Francisco. Paul Kagan died in New York in 1993.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Chiefly photographs created and copied by Kagan while conducting research for his book, New World Utopias: A Photographic History of the Search for Community (New York: Penguin Books, 1975). The photographs document nineteenth and twentieth century utopian communities, most located in California, with others in New Mexico, Pennsylvania, and Tennessee. The collection includes material he collected about utopian communities, including audiotapes of interviews and related events, as well as drawings and photographs. The collection also includes examples of photography and graphic design that Kagan created for traditional and alternative newspapers, as well as examples of some of his book reviews and other writings. A small group of material documents social action at the University of California, Berkeley, and in the San Francisco Bay Area during the 1960s.

Utopian communities and other groups represented in the collection include an Amish community, Ananda Ashrama, Caspar Compound, Divine Light Mission, Esoteric Fraternity, The Farm, Fundación Indra Devi, Fountaingrove, Fountain of the World, Halcyon, Holy City, Icaria Speranza, Kaweah Colony, Krotona (including Happy Valley School), Lama Foundation, Lemurian Fellowship, Llano del Rio, The Lord's Land, Pisgah Faith Home, Pisgah Grande, Point Loma, Rosicrucian Fellowship, Questhaven Retreat, Self-Realization Golden World Colony, Table Mountain Ranch, Tassajara Zen Mountain Center, Theosophical Society (Pasadena), Unification Church, and Vedanta Temple (Santa Barbara).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Photographs of Utopian Communities, 1968-1976. II. Other Material Related to Utopian Communities, circa 1895-circa 1989. III. Personal Papers, 1960-circa 1989.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is organized into three subseries: Photographs by Kagan, Oversize Photographic Prints by Kagan, and Copy Photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series mainly consists of photographic materials created by Kagan in the course of researching New World Utopias: A Photographic History of the Search for Community . A small group of photographs from unidentified sources is also available in Series II. Other Material Related to Utopian Communities.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: Notebook and Original Images by Kagan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries chiefly consists of photographic negatives, contact sheets, and work prints created by Kagan related to utopian communities. Many of the photographs document the ruins or former sites of communities.
Kagan visited some sites more than once. Some rolls of negatives document multiple sites and have been filed together to reflect the rolls.
The subseries also includes a notebook by Kagan that provides background for some of the images, as well as material he copied from others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Spiral-bound notebook with notes about photographs created by Kagan and copied by him, as well as research notes about utopian communities in California.

Notebook also includes draft essays about Tassajara Zen Mountain Center and the United Farm Workers, as well as a review of Janwillem Van de Wetering, A Glimpse of Nothingness: Experiences in an American Zen Community (Boston: Houghton Mifflin St. Martin's Griffin, 1975). Also includes notes related to the custody of his daughter, Colorado M. Kagan (born 1969).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs by Kagan of sites and individuals related to utopian communities. A portion of images appeared in his New World Utopias: A Photographic History of the Search for Community (New York: Penguin Books, 1975).

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Lama Foundation is a community in the mountains of north of Taos, New Mexico, founded in 1967 by Barbara Durkee and Stephen Durkee (later known as Asha Greer or Asha von Briesen and Nooruddeen Durkee).

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Jules Leroux and Armand DeHay established the egalitarian commune of Icaria Speranza in 1881 an area just south of Cloverdale, California. They had emigrated from an Icarian community in Iowa, Jeune Icarie, which had been founded on the principles set forth by in Étienne Cabet (1788-1856), Voyage en Icarie , published in 1840. The settlement dissolved by 1887.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Kaweah Colony was a Marxian Socialist community settled in 1885 along the Kaweah River in the Sierras of eastern Tulare County by the Co-Operative Land Purchase and Colonization Association of California, led by Burnette G. Haskell and James J. Martin, labor activists from San Francisco. In 1890, the Kaweah colonists lost all claims to their land when Congress established the Sequoia National Park, and the community disbanded in 1892.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Krotona, is a colony of the Adyar Theosophists in that settled in Hollywood, California, in 1912. The Krotona colony relocated to Ojai, California in 1926.

In 1946, Jiddu Krishnamurti (1895-1986), Aldous Huxley (1894-1963), Guido Ferrando (1883-1969) and Rosalind Edith Rajagopal (1903-1996) established the Happy Valley School (later known as the Besant Hill School of Happy Valley) in Ojai.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Pisgah Grande (1914-1920) was a Pentecostal Christian community in Las Llajas Canyon of the Santa Susana Mountains, California, founded by Dr. Finis Ewing Yoakum (1851-1920). In 1920, James Cheek (born 1874), moved the colony to Pikesville, Tennessee.

did.unittitle: Pisgah Grande and Fountain of the World

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Fountain of the World, also known as the WKFL (Wisdom, Knowledge, Faith, Love) Foundation was founded circa 1948 by Krishna Venta (1911-1958, born Francis Heindswatzer Pencovic). The lodge for the Fountain of the World was located at Fountain of the World was located in Box Canyon, Canoga Park, California.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Ananda Ashrama was a Vedanta center founded in La Crescenta, California in 1923 by Swami Paramananda (1884-1940).

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: In 1900 Katherine Tingley (1847-1929) moved the headquarters of the Theosophical Society to "Lomaland", a hilltop campus at Point Loma overlooking the ocean in San Diego, California. A theosophical commune developed, which included a Raja-Yoga school in 1900, open air theater in 1901, a college in 1914, and a theosophical university in 1919. The Theosophical Society moved to Covina, California in 1942.

did.physdesc: (12 negatives, 1 contact sheet, and 4 photographic prints)

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Questhaven Retreat is a non-denominational Christian retreat in Escondido, California founded in 1940 by Christian mystic and spiritual teacher Flower A. Newhouse (1909-1994) and her husband, Lawrence George Newhouse (1910-1963).

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Lemurian Fellowship was created by Howard John Zitko (1911–2003) and Robert D. Stelle (1881-1952) in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, inspired by the work of Frederick Spencer Oliver (1866-1899). After a disagreement between them in 1946, Stelle relocated the Lemurian Fellowship to Ramona, California.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Indra Devi (1899-2002), born Eugenie Peterson, was a prominent yoga teacher. In 1961, she established the Fundación Indra Devi in Tecate, Mexico.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Self-Realization Fellowship/Yogoda Satsanga Society of India is a spiritual organization founded in 1920 by Paramahansa Yogananda (1893-1952) and based in Los Angeles, California. The Self-Realization Golden World Colony, also known as a World Brotherhood Colony, in Encinitas, California, was a model community envisioned by Yogananda in 1937 and established by 1947.

did.unittitle: Self-Realization Golden World Colony and Rosicrucian Fellowship

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Rosicrucian Fellowship is an Esoteric Christian fraternal and service organization founded by Max Heindel (1865-1919) in 1909. In 1911, Heindel and his associates established the international headquarters of The Rosicrucian Fellowship on Mount Ecclesia in Oceanside, California.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Theosophical Society (Pasadena) is a successor organization to the original Theosophical Society founded by Helena Petrovna Blavatsky and others in New York City, 1875. In 1950-1951, the headquarters located to Pasadena, California.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Around 1900, Finis Ewing Yoakum (1851-1920), established Yoakum's Sanatorium at his house in the Highland Park neighborhood of Los Angeles, California. The home offered free care to indigents in the main home, as well as cottages, tents, and wagons on the property. By 1903, Yoakum's Sanatorium had became the Pisgah Faith Home.

did.unittitle: Pisgah Faith Home and Vedanta Temple, Santa Barbara

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: In 1944, Spencer Kellogg donated thirty acres in Santa Barbara to the Vedanta Society of Southern California, which included a house, a small shrine and an art room. Since 1947, the site has served as a convent. The temple designed by Lutah Maria Riggs (1896-1984) was dedicated in 1956.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: In 1928, Carrie Mead Wyckoff (1859-1949) gave her home and property in Hollywood, California to Swami Prabhavananda (1893-1976) of the Ramakrishna Order of India. He moved there the following year from Portland, Oregon. In 1934, Prabhavananda established the Vedanta Society of Southern California as a non-profit organization. In 1938, the society completed and dedicated a temple on the property in Hollywood with money donated by Wyckoff.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Bill Carrico? has a connection undocumented in the collection to the Esoteric Fraternity. In 1891, Hiram Erastus Butler (1841-1916) established the Esoteric Fraternity community in Applegate, California. The location also served as the headquarters for the Esoteric Publishing Co., which published books and journals, including The Esoteric: A Magazine of Advanced and Practical Esoteric Thought .

did.physdesc: (22 negatives, 3 contact sheets, and 1 photographic print)

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Halcyon, California, is an intentional Theosophist community and headquarters of a religious organization, The Temple of the People. William Dower and Francia LaDue founded The Temple of the People in Syracuse, New York in 1898 and moved to Halcyon in 1903. Dower and LaDue also established the Halcyon Hotel and Sanatorium. Members of the community farmed and created handicrafts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes discrete portraits of Harold E. Forgostein (1906-1990), the guardian of the temple at Halcyon, and Betty Robertson Warrington (1887-1986), a librarian at Krotona and wife of Albert Powell Warrington (1866-1939), editor of the The American Theosophist .

did.physdesc: (36 negatives, 4 contact sheets, and 2 photographic prints)

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Iverson Louis Harris (1890-1979) was secretary to Katherine Augusta Tingley (1847-1929) a prominent Theosophist and active in Theosophical Society since childhood. He served as Chairman of the Cabinet, 1942-1946. He then left the Theosophical Society over a disagreement about its leadership.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes portraits of Harris and his then fiancée, Katherine Knoche McDonald (born circa 1905) at Point Loma.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Judith M. Tyberg (1902-1980), also known as Jyotipriya, was a scholar of Sanskrit and educated at the Theosophical Society's Point Loma Raja Yoga School and the Theosophical University. In 1953, she founded the East-West Cultural Center in Los Angeles, California, later known as the Sri Aurobindo Center of Los Angeles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Portraits of Rosalind Edith Rajagopal.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The International Ideal City, also known as the Creative Community Project, was a commune in Boonville, California. It was established by Sang Ik Choi, a missionary for the Unification Church.

did.unittitle: International Re-Educational Foundation and Tassajara Zen Mountain Center

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: International Re-Education Foundation in Oakland, California, was established by Sang Ik Choi, a missionary for the Unification Church.
The Tassajara Zen Mountain Center, or Zenshinji (Zen Mind Temple), was established in Carmel Valley Village, California by the San Francisco Zen Center and abbot Shunryu Suzuki (1904-1971) in 1966.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Table Mountain Ranch is a commune established on 120 acres in Albion, California, in 1968.

did.unittitle: Table Mountain Ranch and The Lord's Land

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Lord's Land was a Christian commune founded in 1968 by Sabine Koritke Ball (1925-2009) in Albion, California.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Caspar Compound was a commune in Caspar, California.

did.unittitle: "New World Utopias: The Search for Community in the West, 1876-1975"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Images of an exhibition by Kagan at the Oakland Museum of California, August 9-September 28, 1975, and sponsored by the California Historical Society.

did.physdesc: (108 negatives, 5 contact sheets, and 9 photographic prints)
(482 negatives, 21 contact sheets, and 5 photographic prints)

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Farm is an intentional community founded in 1971 by Stephen Gaskin (born 1935) near the town of Summertown, Tennessee.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Portraits of Nourse and Stevens, former members of the Llano Del Rio, a commune in Llano, California.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Not the Vedanta center in La Crescenta, California.

did.unittitle: Canning operation of Contadina in San Jose, California

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Oversize photograph prints, most 35.6 x 27.9 cm. and occasionally mounted on board, chiefly original images by Kagan of sites and individuals related to utopian communities.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by site, followed by a portrait of Bill Carrico? and images with unidentified locations.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Fountaingrove was a utopian colony near Santa Rosa, California, founded by Thomas Lake Harris (1823-1906) in 1875. Most of its settlers were followers of Harris's Brotherhood of the New Life and relocated with Harris from their previous colony at Brocton, New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: View of Cliff Palace

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a view of the later home of Dr. Finis Ewing Yoakum at 140 South Avenue 59, Los Angeles, California

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes images of an apartment building, a rocking chair in front of a wooden building, forect scene, and a copy photograph of a woman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Copy photographs chiefly created by Kagan from original photographs held by individuals and repositories, as well as from publications. The majority of images appeared in his New World Utopias: A Photographic History of the Search for Community .
Source individuals and repositories are identified in most cases. Consult New World Utopias for descriptions of many of the images.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by site or individual and then chronologically, followed by various photographs from Kagan's personal collection and from unidentified sources.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Reference use only: photographs and negatives in this subseries may not be reproduced.

did.unittitle: Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: From origial photographs owned by Warrington.

did.unittitle: Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery

scopecontent.p: Includes maps of California.

did.unittitle: Pisgah Faith Home and Pisgah Grande

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Reverend Harold James Smith (died 1994) was director from 1950-1993 of Christ Faith Mission Inc., which purchased the Pisgah Faith Home after 1920.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes portraits of Smith in front of the Pisgah Faith Home

did.physdesc: (54 negatives, 3 contact sheets, and 9 photographic prints)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes portraits by of Kagan of Harris' sister-in-law.

did.unittitle: Various images from Kagan's personal collection of utopian material
Other Material Related to Utopian Communities

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is organized into two subseries: Audiotapes and Material Related to Utopian Communities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series mainly consists of materials collected by Kagan related to utopian communities, as well as his own work with traditional and alternative newspapers, and social action activities in and around the University of California, Berkeley, and the San Francisco Bay area.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Restricted fragile material. Reference copies are available in the same box as original tapes. Consult Access Services for further information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reel-to-reel recordings made by of Kagan of interviews and events chiefly related to utopian communities, as well as recordings of dialogues between Jiddu Krishnamurti and Jacob Needleman (born 1934) distributed by the Krishnamurti Foundation.
Descriptions taken from the original boxes that housed the tapes.

did.materialspec: The program is distorted at times. There is high background noise on the tape.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Harold A. Parker (1878-1930) was a professional photographer active in Pasadena, California, 1900-1930.

did.unittitle: Photographic portrait of an Asian American woman
Photographs of the Krotona Inn by the Arts and Crafts Guild

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Arts and Crafts Guild was a group of artisans and photographers working within the Krotona colony in Hollywood, California.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs of the Krotona Inn (also known as Krotona Court) was built in Hollywood, California, in 1912-1913.

did.unittitle: Hand-tinted photographs of the Krotona Inn and Grand Temple of the Rosy Cross

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Grand Temple of the Rosy Cross, built 1914, was an auditorium of the Krotona Colony.

did.unittitle: Lama Foundation, Poster with a figure of an angel and child
Divine Light Mission (Divya Sandesh Parishad), Poster advertising a lecture by Prem Rawat (born 1957, also known as Maharaj Ji and Balyogeshwar)

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Divine Light Mission (Divya Sandesh Parishad) was an organization founded in 1960 by Shri Hans Ji Maharaj (1900-1966). It gained prominence under the leadership of his fourth and youngest son, Prem Rawat.

did.unittitle: Clipping, Lillian M. Snyder, "Icarian Emigration to Nauvoo Outlined" in Macomb Daily Journal (Macomb, Illinois)

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Lillian M. Snyder (1914-2005) was a descendent Emile Baxter (died 1895), who was a member of the Board of Directors and Secretary of the first chartered Icarian colony in Nauvoo, Illinois.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Article, "Utopian Studies Center Planned for Next Year," discusses the establishment of the center with Kagan as its director.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is organized into two subseries: Works by Kagan, and University of California, Berkeley, and the San Francisco Bay Area

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Examples of photographs and graphic design that Kagan created for alternative newspapers and music venues, primarily in the San Francisco Bay area of California, as well as book reviews he wrote for New York Times Book Review . It also includes material related to social action activities in and around the University of California, Berkeley, and the San Francisco Bay area.

did.unittitle: Flier for concerts by Robbie Basho and John Fahey at The Jabberwock, Berkeley, California, created by Kagan and Tom Weller
City of San Francisco Oracle (San Francisco, California) Volume 1, No. 7

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes photographs by Kagan, including several depicting a conversation among of Allen Ginsberg (1926-1997), Timothy Leary (1920-1996), Gary Snyder (born 1930), and Alan Watts (1915-1973).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Cover photograph by Kagan of Allen Ginsberg with a child.

scopecontent.p: Flier that includes a photograph by Kagan of Allen Ginsberg with a child.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes photographs by Kagan of country rock band Commander Cody and His Lost Planet Airmen, as well as a view of the Fox Theater Oakland in Oakland, California.

scopecontent.p: Includes group portrait of Allen Ginsberg, Timothy Leary, Gary Snyder, and Alan Watts by Kagan.

did.unittitle: University of California, Berkeley, and the San Francisco Bay Area

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Independent newspaper created by former staff members of the Daily Californian student newspaper at University of California, Berkeley.

did.unittitle: Student election materials for SLATE campaign

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: A group of student leaders organized SLATE in February 1958, which included former members of a campus political party, TASC (Towards an Active Student Community) and other previously unaffiliated students, and proposed they run as a "slate" for student government office.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Study of graffiti written for an anthropology class. It discusses graffiti at the University of California, Berkeley, the National Autonomous University of Mexico, in elementary and secondary schools, in neighborhoods throughout San Francisco, and in jails.

did.unittitle: Flier about Planning the 20th Reunion of the Free Speech Movement at University of California, Berkeley
